tweet: Facebook reported the fastest revenue growth in over five years, bolstered by a hot ad market. The social media giant warned it could be hard to top these boom times. Says revenue growth to slow this year; shares drop 3% in after-hours trading.

History says stocks could be due for selloff: S&P500 bottomed on Mar23, 2020, which means we’re 3mths into Year2 of bull mkt. Since 1945, bull mkts saw avg drawdown of 10% during Yr2 – ranged from -5% to -16%. Since Mar23, 2021, S&P seen max drawdown of 4%

Facebook joined the $1 TRILLION CLUB after comp wins dismissal of US, states’ monopoly lawsuits. Judge says FTC failed to meet burden Facebook has monopoly. FTC can refile complaint within 30 days, judge says in ruling.

S&P 500 closed week at another ATH, printing best weekly performance since Feb, albeit shallow breadth of rally may be a warning signal, BBG’s Ye Xie writes. 48% of S&P 500 members trading >50d moving average, the lowest percentage since 1999, suggesting the rally lacks momentum.

The S&P 500 may have hit a new ATH today at 4,277 points, +13.8% YTD, but if you put the index in relation to Fed's balance sheet, it is trading at the same level as in 2008, so equities have traded sideways since 2008, basically counteracting balance sheet expansion.

Fed's Powell tries to sound a bit more dovish Discussing liftoff now would be highly premature. Powell says this meeting was the 'talking about talking about' meeting. Dow pares some losses, US 10y yields come off today's highs.

Just to put things into perspective: W/its current cash reserve of $195bn, Apple could in theory either buy entire HUI or, buy roughly 3,330 tons of gold, Incrementum has calculated. If latter were to happen, Apple would become world’s 2nd-largest gold holder after US Treasury.
Honky Tonk Warren: Berkshire Hathaway’s questionable performance and governance. The world’s most famous conglomerate will struggle to outlast its feted founder in its current form.

Goldman says proposed US capital gains tax hike will limit S&P 500 upside. Estimates $1+ tn in unrealized cap gains for wealthiest US households, equal to 3% of US mkt cap & roughly 30% of avg monthly S&P 500 trading vol. Past tax hikes have been associated w/declines in prices.

OUCH! Dow plunges 400 points on fears of higher capital gains taxes. BBG reports that Biden is planning a capital gains tax hike to as high as 43.4% for wealthy Americans. Proposal would hike capital gains rate to 39.6% for those earning >$1mln, up from 20% currently.

Just to put things into perspective: The S&P 500 may have hit a new ATH today, but if you put the index in relation to the Fed's balance sheet, it is trading at the same level as in 2008, so equities have traded sideways since 2008, basically counteracting balance sheet expansion

Facebook shares hit fresh record, w/ social-media company taking out a peak that has stood since Aug as fears fade about impact of new privacy policies from Apple. $FB also got a positive mention in Barron’s, which said Facebook is a “growth machine” and its stock could gain 20%
Americans signal they’ll spend stimulus on travel, Not GameStop. Questions whether third federal checks will flow into stocks. Google search trends for travel reach an all-time high.

VIX Futures return to pre-pandemic level: The new week started with some calm, as the S&P 500 set another record high & the first VIX futures contract closed at lowest level in more than a year, BBG reports: That may signal lingering fears of pandemic are finally starting to fade

Hey guys, in tdy's  podcast AAA we discuss great rotation from 'story stocks' to pandemic losers. We ask whether Apple, w/mkt cap of $2.1tn, can still grow. We discuss the hype surrounding Magna International as possible Apple car supplier. MUST HEAR!

Hey guys, don't miss our new  Podcast AAA. We discuss transition at Amazon and ask whether Andy Jassy will continue to invest vs. worrying about near-term profit as Bezos did. We look at the largest IPO in Germany since 2019: Auto1 Group. MUST HEAR!

Hey guys, you could do me a small favor! We just launched our daily Podcast AAA. It's doing well on Spotify. But in order for us to pass tipping point on Apple Podcast as well, it would be wonderful if you would just listen in, give it 5 stars & subscribe.

Love this question from  If the US govt were a company would you buy it? With the US govt having $27.8tn of total debt outstanding and $3.4tn of revenue, would you ever buy that company over one (S&P500) that has $5.5tn of debt and $11.3tn of revenues?

Global stocks climbed to ATH on optimism that fiscal spending will revive growth & bolster corp earnings. S&P500 posted best 1d reaction to presidential inauguration since at least 1937.  Bonds steady w/US 10y 1.08%. Dollar weaker w/Euro $1.21 ahead of ECB. Gold 1868, Bitcoin 35k
Amazon, Apple, Google ban Parler app over violent content around Capitol attack. Amazon Web Services plans to stop hosting Parler Sunday. Parler says services may be affected by up to a week.

What does Mr Market want to tell us? That Tesla will crush all of its car competition? That Tesla will have margins with its cars like Apple? That Tesla will become an integrated green electrification company? Tesla is on its way to becoming a $1tn comp w/just 500k cars sold.
Mind the gap between Wall St and Main St. W/a blue sweep, the gap could be closed as the avg US worker must now work >141 hours to buy 1 share of S&P 500.

Byron Wien says S&P 500 will tumble before rallying to 4,500. Forecast calls for 20% drawdown. Sees US GDP to grow by >6%, causing the 10y Treasury yield to rise to 2%. Expects that Trump will start his own TV network to boost his 2024 campaign.

The January effect should help support the constructive stimulus + vaccine backdrop for global equities this month, JPM says: On average, MSCI World has risen by +1.1% and +2.2% in January over the last 30Y and 10Y respectively.

Wells Fargo's top predictions for 2021 incl warning for Tesla investors: Tesla could become AOL. „AOL, similar to Tesla, had game changing technology, incredible performance & it goes into S&P500 late in year in Dec after amazing run," Wells’s Harvey says

This chart highlights how crazy 2020 was: Retail investors have taken command of the stock mkts. Their stock outperformed the S&P 500 by >70ppts this year. Robinhood investors may hear “Irrational Exuberance” warnings but they will smile and buy shares anyway.
VW's CEO says cash-rich technology giants invading the auto industry pose a much bigger challenge than traditional rivals like Toyota. Says Apple can mount major challenge w/ Auto push.

Tesla’s historic entry into S&P 500 could create risk in S&P. Comps to face selling pressure as carmaker joins index, Citadel Securities Trading chief says. Danger is that trading in many stocks may not be active enough to absorb a sudden deluge of supply

Rob Arnott warns Tesla stock is showing signs of a bubble & indexers are about to buy high. Shares of Elon Musk’s electric-car maker will probably lag the S&P 500 in the year after its looming entry to the index, the Research Affiliates founder said.

Could stock splits be the new tool after share buybacks to drive prices? Avg price of a stock in the S&P 500 currently at an ATH high of $165, SRP has calculated.  While stock splits shouldn't theoretically create any economic value, they could irrationally boost share prices.
Mind the gap between S&P 500 and Smart Money Index. While the S&P 500 trades near ATH, the SMI is at near an 2y low. This dichotomy will end, in one direction or the other. (HT

Just to put things into perspective or the rising wealt inequality in one chart: The average US worker must now work 141 hours to buy 1 share of S&P 500. That's, of course, a fresh record. In the 1980s, it took less than 20 hours.

Call it the Amazon economy or retail apocalypse: Of the 344,000 US private-sector jobs created in Nov, 38% tie to on-line retail & good number of these jobs may end w/holiday shipping season,  says. These are jobs at couriers & messengers, warehouses, & trucking comps

The risky power of passive! Tesla will be added to the S&P 500 in one shot on Dec. 21, forcing money managers to adjust their portfolios to make room for the $538bn company. Musk shares have gained since Index addition announcement.
Trump said the stock market would crash if Biden won. The Dow just had its best month since 1987. Jumped almost 12% in Nov.

Tesla’s S&P 500 debut in Dec will put $100bn in trades in motion as asset managers are compelled to account for the stock. No one has ever tried to add a $555bn comp into S&P 500. That’s happening next month, and it’s causing headaches across Wall St.

European equities should benefit from a global value rally, JPM says. EU vs US equities’ performance (Stoxx600 vs S&P500) has historically tracked Global Value vs Growth, & interestingly despite Value’s weight in Europe having fallen off late, correlation has continued this year.

Good morning from Germany, which has one of the longest-serving heads of states. Today, German Chancellor Angela Merkel is 15 years and one day in office. Under her aegis, the benchmark index Dax may have outperformed Europe, but not MSCI World and certainly not the Dow Jones.

Battered active managers see salvation in churning market. With S&P 500 no longer ruled by just 5 names, active investors may finally have found kind of target-rich environment where their skills thrive.   HT

Just to put things into perspective:  If added today, Telsa would rank as the 8th largest S&P 500 constituent. Measured by the P/E ratio, it would be one of the most expensive stocks in the index. (Chart via Goldman)

Good morning from Germany, where benchmark index Dax is about to undergo major reform. On Tue, index operator Deutsche Börse will decide whether the index will be increased from 30 to 40 stocks. If Dax is calculated like Dow Jones w/o dividends, it has not moved since year 2000.
Tesla will join the S&P 500 Index in Dec as largest-ever new member. Shares spike in late trading. Elon Musk fortune jumps $15bn on Tesla’s S&P inclusion.

Due to large size of Tesla addition into S&P 500, S&P Dow Jones Indices is seeking feedback through consultation to investment community to determine if Tesla should be added all at once on rebalance effective date or in 2 separate tranches ending on rebalance effective date.

Stocks slump w/S&P 500 closed down 1.5% on lockdown angst amid stimulus limbo. New York City could close schools again as Covid cases surge. White House said to step back from negotiations on fresh aid.

Dow surges >500 points, heads for best week since April as post-election rally continues w/investors rushed back into Big Tech & health-care firms on bets that US election results will mean no major tax hikes or regulatory changes that would derail sectors.

WHAT? US election jam bolsters Big Tech as a safe haven. Tech stocks like Facebook & Alphabet rose more than non-tech peers after neither Trump nor Biden got a quick win. Likely DC paralysis means tech giants should escape most damaging antitrust backlash.

Even if you’d known current state of play you would'nt have guessed mkt reaction so far, DB says. Pre-election Blue Wave was seen to be most risk-friendly outcome. Now US pres election could still go either way but mkts not overly concerned. S&P Future +1%, Vix <30, US 10y 0.82%.

Combined mkt cap of FANGMAN (Facebook, Apple, Netflix, Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Nvidia) has lost $300bn as latest batch of tech earnings is stoking concern that Big Tech may have reached an inflection point. Better-than-expected results haven’t been enough for rallies.

Asset-Light Recovery: The S&P 500's epic rally is powered by assets you can't see or touch. Intangible assets make up more than 84% of S&P 500 firm value. Covid is pushing this share higher at the expense of workers.

US Justice Department will file an antitrust lawsuit alleging that Google engaged in anticompetitive conduct to preserve monopolies in & search-advertising that form cornerstones of its conglomerate. Lawsuit seeks to break comps grip over search traffic.

Dow rallies >500 points for its best day since July after President Trump tweeted support for aid to airlines and other stimulus measures, stoking hope that a smaller aid package could be passed by lawmakers.

Good Morning from Germany where dividends matter & artificially dope benchmark index Dax. Without dividends, German stocks' return since 2000 high would be negative. While Dax has gained 60% since then, Dax Price Index, which like S&P500 does not incl dividends, has dropped 11.1%
Spain's 10y risk premium over Germany rises slightly after S&P cut Spain’s credit outlook to negative from stable.  Acc to S&P, Spain's GDP will not return to 2019 levels until 2022.

Looks as if mkts ignore looming crisis in Spain. S&P cut Spain’s credit outlook to neg from stable citing weak pol response to rising econ & fiscal challenges. Pandemic has hit Spain’s econ hard; GDP will not return to 2019 levels until 2022, S&P says. But ylds near lows of year

The Tech Bubble could get even bigger, Barron’s says in cover story: Recent correction doesn't mean that the bubble is ready to burst. The forces that have inflated Apple, Amazon, Zoom, and other tech stocks could be w/us for a while. That suggests this market could keep climbing

A telecom provider (Softbank) gambled around w/call options. Imagine the IBM boss would suddenly buying options w/shareholders' money. Softbank's Masa Son reconsiders trading strategy that hurt shares after Facebook, Microsoft and Netflix bets turn sour.
S&P Call-Put-ratio at ATH. Stock mkt performance amplified by options usage witnessing a classic fragility shock. Where & when will the policy put kick in,? BofA asks.

OOPS! Tesla falls >6% in after-hours trading after not being included in S&P500. The electric carmaker has reported a fourth consecutive quarterly profit, making it eligible for inclusion in the S&P 500. The index rebalances 4 times a year, but committee can add at other times.

Don't miss our Guru piece in today's  We show how a DCF model can be used to find promising stocks if a permanently lower discount rate is assumed. Among the candidates w/a high guru factor are Tesla, Amazon, Zoom or DocuSign. via

Will history repeat? Abe’s previous resignation, in 2007, was followed by period of underperformance for Japanese stocks & a stronger Yen. Topix fell 18% in 6mth period after announcement, vs only -7% for MSCI ACWI. The Yen strengthened 12% against the dollar, BBG has calculated.
Just to put things into perspective: The average US worker must now work 128 hours to buy 1 share of S&P 500. That's almost a record. In the 1980s, it took less than 20 hours.

OOPS! Tesla has posted 4 quarters of positive earnings. That’s enough to get it into the S&P 500, right? Not necessarily. Tesla would not have made money on a generally accepted accounting principles basis w/o the sale of regulatory credits to carmakers.

WHAT? Salesforce will replace ExxonMobil, and Amgen will replace Pfizer, and Honeywell International will replace Raytheon Technologies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average effective prior to the opening of trading on Aug. 31.

Betting on US equity selloff: Hedge funds slowly boosting their bearish bets. Net short positions in S&P 500 E-mini futures have hit their highest in 2mths, BBG reports. Stretched valuations & deteriorating relationship between Washington and Beijing may pave way for a pullback.

Was Dave Portnoy on to something when he suggested that Warren Buffett, the "Oracle of Omaha", might be past his prime? Berkshire cash pile jumps to fresh ATH of $146.6bn in Q2, showing Buffett has missed strong Q2 rally. Berkshire stock has lagged S&P 500

Better than Apple! Shares of MSCI has gained 2,088% since IPO in 2007 even beating Tech Giant as index providers like MSCI, S&P Global, LSE (FTSE Russell) or Deutsche Börse have minted money w/ETF craze. Stocks expensive but may have more upside.   via

Main business model of Ireland, tax haven for tech giants, can continue. Apple has €13bn Irish tax bill overturned. Apple, Google, Facebook & Co collectively all take advantage of Ireland's favorable conditions & shift billions of dollars in profits there

It looks like this year that Main St (retail investor) will beat Wall St (institutional investors) in the markets. Goldman Sachs Retail Basket w/Robinhood Favs has gained +24%Ytd while Dow Jones down -8% YTD.

Tesla shares went ballistic this evening. Jumps >1.5k w/some believing the comp could report a 4th consecutive GAAP profit and thus be eligible to enter the S&P 500 index. Mkt cap now $287bn, more than 3 times VW's mkt cap.
The costs of bad market timing decisions in 2020 are back-breaking: Missing the best 5days would have led to a loss of 30%. Temptation to call the peak grows after S&P500's 40% rally.

Facebook’s widening ad exodus means more risks to rev growth. Starbucks, Levi Strauss said they too will pause spending. Growing number steepens peer pressure: It is very visible who is & isn't participating in boycott where brand silence = being complicit

Pressure on Facebook's Zuckerberg keeps rising as Coca-Cola pauses advertising on all social media platforms. Dockers & Levi’s also announced they will be pausing ads on Facebook & Instagram, while Hershey’s said it will be cutting spending by a third.

Dow closes 157.62 points higher as Fed announcement sparks big comeback from massive losses. The Fed said it would buy individual corp bonds, marking a broader approach to corporate bond buying. Dow traded 762.36 points lower before rebounding.
So you know who you can send the thank-you note to! S&P 500 wiped out 2020 loss as global liquidity hit a fresh ATH at $85.5tn.

Facebook & the creation of a US oligarch. To stay this big and unregulated, the social media platform can’t afford to upset rulers. Its goals, to make Croesus-style profits & stay as big as possible, are aligned with Mr Trump’s goal of winning a 2nd term

Dax is much better than his reputation. Since its launch, Germany's benchmark index has far outperformed MSCI World by 360ppts. And it is now renewing itself. Deutsche Wohnen is replacing Lufthansa. Tech comps like Zalando could soon be in index.   via

Wall St mixed w/Dow lower, Nasdaq higher as traders continue to assess just how strong econ recovery may be as states reopen, set against stock mkt that has recovered most of its ytd losses. Investors dismissing bank loan losses, lack of buybacks, dividend cuts, glob uncertainty.

Italy bonds rally w/10y risk spread over Germany plunges to 235bps as Moody’s hints that it could hold off downgrading Italy to junk. Moody’s currently ranks Italy as Baa3, its lowest investment grade, w/review scheduled for May8. S&P will review Italy rating this evening.

Wall St rose for the first time in 3 days as investors bought the dip. Dow surges >400 points or 2% as Oil jumps 19%, clawing back some of the recent losses and as investors digest a slew of 1Q20 earnings releases that sparked speculation a recovery will be sooner than expected.

ECB will hold call on Wed where policymakers may discuss whether to accept junk-rated debt as collateral from banks as Italy faces downgrade. S&P set to review Italy’s rating on Fri, which it currently ranks 2 notches above investment grade w/neg outlook.

Dow Jones drops almost 600 points or 2.4% amidst a historic oil plunge as investors assess how deep and how long the current recession will last, and how prepared Corp America is to weather the storm of the current shutdown and the global slowdown.
Don‘t mess with the bears. Don’t miss our new  Podcast deffnerundzschaepitz. You can find that on Apple Podcast, Spotify, Google Podcast or wherever good podcasts can be found. @ Berlin, Germany

Bold market calls abound as Guggenheim's Minerd says the S&P 500 could drop 40%. JPMorgan says the worst is already past, and that there is potential for S&P 500 to rally back up to 2,850. Goldman has said the gauge could fall to 2,000 before recovering.

Dow Jones plunges 3,000 points or 13% in worst rout since 1987 crash as coronavirus market collapse continues. Ends at lowest level since 2017 as Wall St fears mount that virus will tip US economy into recession.
Goldman Sachs warns S&P 500 might not bottom until 2,000. Equity strategist Kostin sees at least another 10% drop. Sell-off could get to 41% if economic fallout deepens.
Dow Future plunges 840 after Fed's second emergency rate cut points as Trump says market should be 'thrilled' at Fed's surprise rate cut.

S&P cut the outlook on Malta to stable from positive citing the global spread of the coronavirus which will hit the small and open economy. Country's reputational risks related to weaknesses in anti-money-laundering supervision represent an increasing risk to macro-fin stability

Wall St stocks drop 3% as Goldman Sachs calls the end of the bull market. "After 11yrs, 13% annualized earnings growth & 16% annualized trough-to-peak appreciation, we believe S&P 500 bull mkt will soon end. Cut their S&P 500 forecast to 2,450 by mid-2020, drop of 14% from today.

Dow sinks more >2,000 points in worst day since 2008. S&P 500 tripped 7% circuit breaker in early trading as investors react to ~30% decline in oil, concerns that such a drop may pressure credit mkts, driving 10y US yields down to <0.50%, & ongoing uncertainty around coronavirus.

Despite sharp equity position reduction by institutional investors during last week of Feb, JPM says that equity position metrics are overall some way from capitulation levels of Dec2018. It would take another 4% decline in S&P 500 from here for z-score to reach an extreme level.

Just to put things into perspective: US investors remain a bit tentative, not as robust as index gain (+4.2%) would suggest. Can be seen in which sectors are working & which are not. Healthcare best performing sector in S&P today, At the bottom of performance sits Energy & Hotels

Mad markets. Wall St jumps, w/ Dow Jones up 1,293.96 points >5.1%, biggest percentage gain since 2009, fueled by hopes central banks will act in concert to offset any impact from the spreading coronavirus.

It looks like US President Trump is more concerned w/the stock market rout than the corona epidemic as S&P500 posted worst week since 2008. Trump calls for Fed rate cuts. Says ‘markets will all come back.’
Fed to the rescue! Dow paring some losses as Fed Chairman Powell said the Federal Reserve will 'act as appropriate to support the economy'
Netflix is this year’s undisputed FAANG winner as stock will do quite well despite coronavirus and recession fear. Has gained 20% ytd vs Facebook's -6%

It is the end of the decade-long rally? Coronavirus may say „yes." MSCI All-Country Index has dropped >7% over 6d run, while S&P 500 fell 5th straight session for a total 8% decline  RBC, Cantor, Citi talking about S&P 500 bear-mkt levels.   (via

Big Tech made it to cover of The Economist as Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Facebook has gained combined mkt cap of $2tn in past 12mths, equal to entire German stock mkt. To justify this, Tech earning would have to double. BUT this will attract attention of global regulators.

Maybe it needs $1.4tn comp to sound alarm bell: Apple warns that quarterly rev would fall short of $63-67bn guidance it gave few wks ago b/c of supply&demand shock in China. Ripple effects from coronavirus may become apparent, hit mkts in complacency mode.
Rising US wealth inequality in one chart: US workers must work an average of 129.4 hours to afford 1 share of S&P500, a fresh record and 3 times as much as 10yrs ago.

Good morning from Germany, where stock mkt is doing much worse than reported. Although Dax has set fresh record this week. But that is b/c it includes dividends as so-called performance index. If it were calculated like the Dow Jones w/o dividends, it would be far from records.

Totally crazy! Could Tesla be worth $8,000 a share to Google? The price paid would be $1,500 a share, or $270bn. The value ultimately realized by Google could be $1.5tn. That’s more than 10 times higher than today’s valuation and, $8,000 a share.
Founder of world’s largest hedge fund says ‘cash is trash’ as the Dow soars to records. Ray Dalio says at WEF20 investors should be buying this market, rather than seeking safety in cash.

GK expects tech selection similar to dotcom bust 20yrs ago. Failed IPO of WeWork & disappointing Uber performance undermined assumption that 1stmover advantage could turn mkts such as taxis, logistics, entertainment, food delivery into monopolies comparable to Google, FB, Amazon.
Just to put things into perspective: The average US worker must now work 126 hours to buy 1 share of S&P 500. That's a fresh record. In the 1980s, it took less than 20 hours. (Idea via

Netflix was best-performing stock of decade, delivering >4,000% return vs S&P500's 189%. A $1mln bet placed on Jan1, 2010, would be worth close to $43mln today. Joined S&P 500 in 2010, replacing NYT, but found itself mired in deep crisis in following year.
Looks as if US outperformance is close to an end. MSCI US has outperformed MSCI World ex-US in the last decade, the next decade could belong to the rest of the world.

Markets get a dose of clarity. It may not last. The UK must now negotiate a free-trade deal with the EU, while in the U.S. there is the small matter of a presidential election. MSCI Index ex-US way below ATH.

Recession fears are over. Which might not be good, BBG‘s Authers writes. The last time Google Trends saw a peak in recession searches followed by a sudden wave of relief like we saw over the summer was...in early 2008. We know what happened next!
Ouch! S&P Future falls after Trump damps hopes of imminent trade deal. Says it might be better to wait until 2020 election for China trade deal.

Deutsche Bank has turned neutral on US stock market for 1st time in a decade as US mkts may have got ahead of themselves. Sees S&P 500 at 3,250 at end-2020, same as end-2019 target, reflecting modest (+6%) in corp earnings & modest decline in multiple (to around 18.5 from 19.1).

Hey guys, in our new  podcast we debate 'most hated' stock market rally & whether liquidity-filled boom will continue. And after Apple Card social accident we discuss whether Apple compromises iPhone user experience to upsell its services. MUST HEAR!

S&P is up 8% since start of Oct rally, a powerful move that in the past has typically been part of V-shaped recovery. The inexorable logic of late-stage bull mkt means future returns will be lower than in past, even if a recession can be avoided for now.

Don't be evil: Google has announced a major change to its online advertising business that it said would enhance user privacy but which advertisers warned would give the search giant even more power. Google has just surpassed Amazon in mkt cap.

Reminds me on  weapons of math destruction: Apple co-founder Wozniak urges tougher regulation on credit algorithms following probe into Goldman credit card practices. Wozniak said he can borrow 10* as much as his wife on their Apple Cards.
S&P 500 rises >3k, 27 points shy of a fresh ATH, on earnings optimism. But the markets seem to completely negate a US recession that would squeeze the profits of US companies.

Why Facebook’s Libra might be a good thing: When comps threatened w/retaliation by powerful politicians merely for exploring a radical new business idea, it doesn’t bode well for innovation. That is what has happened w/cryptocurrency project, Libra.

Is ultra-loose monetary policy based on incorrectly calculated inflation data? S&P said ECB should include homeowners’ costs in housing calculations. If ECB had been targeting this higher inflation measure, they might have refrained from restarting QE.
Trump: I will respond to new China tariffs Friday afternoon. Dow Jones drops in Risk-Off move.

S&P 500 rally on borrowed time as the 2s10s yield curve has inverted. However, when the S&P 500 will top is unclear. According to historical precedent, it can happen in as little as one month or take more than a year, BofAML data show.
Will the Fed cut intra-meeting as financial conditions tightens and volatility rises? Wall Street extends losses on escalating trade war. S&P500 down 2.5% while fear index VIX up 28%.

Talk of ‚mid-cycle adjustment' sends stocks lower. That might be disappointing to those who've believed that the Fed was making moves to support an economy in its late stages of expansion. Dow Jones down 1%.

Apple badly needs new hit product amid slowing iPhone sales as services can’t offset drag. Microsoft has risen past $1tn in value on strength of Office & fast-growing cloud business. Apple losing pace just as MSFT getting 2nd wind. (Chart

You wouldn't make 5x leveraged bet on S&P 500. Stocks are too volatile. But millions of Americans make 5x lev bets on their homes, that's what it means to put just 20% down. BUT over long run, any given home is likely to experience price vol of ~15% per yr

"I'm 'not a fan' of cryptocurrencies, and Facebook may need a banking charter for Libra," US President Trump says in a series of Tweets. Trump joins other govt leaders & CenBank chiefs incl Fed's Powell, French FinMin Le Maire & BoE's Carney.

Hey guys, we argue in our new  Podcast whether new Facebook Coin Libra will mean start of Hayekian currency competition & whether Libra is curse or blessing for Bitcoin. We debate whether France's Macron is a phoney or messias. Must hear!
The everything rally continues w/ S&P 500 hit fresh all-time high and US 10y yields below 2% driven by bets the Fed will lower interest rates 3 times this year.
Facebook wants it's Libra cryptocurrency to rival the US Dollar one day. Will Facebook’s new initiative to create a cryptocurrency do the same for money as AOL once did for the internet?

What? President Trump, gearing up for the official start of his 2020 campaign, warned that the U.S. would face an epic stock market CRASH if he’s not re-elected. Dow Jones’ performance under Trump so far has been middling.
The US now requiring Visa applicants to list Social-Media names. An estimated 14 million travellers and 710,000 immigrants to the US each year will be affected by the changes

Uber's IPO was supposed to usher in new era for Wall Street: UFAANG. That ungainly acronym, envisioned by some at Morgan Stanley as hype grew over Uber, should put ride-hailing comp in same league as tech titans: Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix & Google
Uber’s dull thud may startle unicorn herd. The lack of positive excitement for the biggest listing of a U.S. technology company since Facebook in 2012 suggests investors are becoming more choosy.

Dow Jones drops in tandem w/US 10y yields as investors taking the trade risk more seriously than was the case Mon thx to WH press briefing. Keep in mind that this time last week most investors assumed a tentative trade détente would be reached by Fri (5/10), JPM warns.
Uber has billed itself as the “Amazon of transportation.” But can it make money?

Dow drops 163points on fading Fed cut anticipation after way less dovish Powell. But even after the Wall St dip, it seems like there is still too much “insurance cut” speculation in equities right now that will need to bleed out in the coming days, JPM says.
President Trump, renewing his attack on the Fed, claimed the stock market (presumably the Dow) would be 5-10k points higher had it not been for the actions of the US Central Bank.
Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos to keep 75% of his stock in divorce. MacKenzie Bezos will keep 25%. Her Amazon stake worth about $36bn. Will be the world's 4th richest woman after divorce.
S&P 500 posts best Quarter in nearly 10yrs, but may need trade deal to boost performance in 2nd quarter.

Hey guys, in our new  podcast we discuss the madness of negative interest rates & whether this will ruin paper money system. We discuss whether Apple's expensive reinvention as a services company will bear fruit. Hear us, share us, leave some reviews!

Looks as if earnings estimates still too high. Cass Freight Index in Shipments has turned negative. Given strong relationship between S&P earnings & freight volumes, weakness in Cass data could translate into more earnings cuts, Quill’s  writes.
Valid or voodoo? Modern Monetary Theory (MMT) may appeal in Europe's 'age of rage.‘ "MMT" is a more searched term on Google than "ECB".
Valid or voodoo? Modern Monetary Theory (MMT) may appeal in Europe's 'age of rage.‘ "MMT" is a more searched term on Google than "ECB".

Dow dropped despite dovish Fed surprise: dots knocked down by more than exp in aggregate: from 2 to 0 this yr & nearly to zero for ’20. Pace of balance sheet shrinkage will begin to slow over coming mths, starting in May & wrap up by Sep. BUT dovish Fed reignited slowdown angst.

Goldman expects share buybacks of S&P 500 comps to rise by 15% this year to $940bn. Buyback craze will not continue given all these leveraged-up comps w/ 50% of the comps are triple-B, so there’s no more releveraging of the balance sheet possible. Companies have no choice.

MSCI to >quadruple weighting of China stocks as bull market builds. Chinese A shares ultimately rising to 3.3% of the MSCI Emerging Markets Index in November from 0.72% today and will occur in three stages.
And let's assume that the interest on deposits will turn positive. That would totally devastate Bundesbank's P&L.

This is the place where S&P 500 rallies have come to die: S&P rises 7th time in 8 weeks even as earnings outlook dims. ‘Don’t get caught up in price momentum,’ MS says as 2019 could be the first in three years w/earnings recession, meaning neg YoY growth.

Dow jumps 1.5% as balance sheet flexibility is just the dovish stance equity investors will love. FOMC holds rates as expected, unanimous but Fed removes reference to further gradual rate increases. Fed says it’s prepared to adjust balance sheet normalization.

And of course, George Soros holds court today at WEF19. His fiery speech against Facebook was probably the most consequential thing to come out of Davos last year. This year, he may go after China with all guns blazing, at his annual dinner at the Seehof,  says.

QE infinity is all the talk in Davos at WEF19: Bridgewater's Dalio says monetary policy will be easier than factored into markets. UBS's Weber says normalizing rates this cycle is 'mission aborted.' G3 Balance sheets and MSCI World Index move in lockstep. Davos

Fed rate hike expectations drive in tandem w/S&P 500. Fed fund futures now pricing in a small chance of a hike by Dec, after anticipating a cut only a couple weeks ago, BBG shows. The more S&P 500 rallies, the higher probability of further hikes. This correlation will cap rallies

S&P 500 is at a critical juncture. Past episodes suggest stock markets will either continue to rally or take another decisive plunge lower, TSL's  writes. Easier Fed policy helps, but global macro data could deteriorate further in 2019. The main risk is a recession.

Gundlach is worried that if growth slows & stocks slump, Treasury yields may actually rise given tsunami of debt markets face. He thinks the S&P 500 would need to fall 30% from its peak for the Fed to begin altering its balance sheet policy.

The FANGMAN complex has gained >$400bn from Dec24 low, led by Netflix, Nvidia, Facebook, Amazon, all stocks w/structural competitive advantages in their industries that should sustain growth even in a slowing econ. Netflix alone has gained 44% since Christmas Eve, $45bn mkt cap.
It looks as if the rally in the S&P 500 could only continue if the Fed suspends its balance sheet shrinking. Markets are dependent on Fed liquidity.

The new year is only a few days old when an apparent “flash crash” has hit currency markets. It took 7 minutes for the Yen to surge through levels that have held through almost a decade. Apple’s rev cut may have been a trigger Algorithms may be cause.

Asia stocks limp into year-end after miraculous US rebound. Dow rose >800 points in <2hours. US govt remained shutdown, could have effects on consumer & business sentiment. Japan 10y ylds fall <0 first time since 2017, Gold continues to rise as traders looked for havens from vol.
Dow Industrials post first-ever 1,000 Point gain in a session. But the joy may be short-lived: Next year is when the trade war chickens will finally come home to roost.

Bad year fur bulls: Wells Fargo cut estimates for stocks next year on concern the Fed is making a pol mistake that will throttle econ. Strategist Chris Harvey cut his 2019 year-end target for S&P 500 to 2,665 from 3,079. Harvey now least bullish strategist

Wall St continues to fall as there is 0 appetite to step in and buy. S&P 500 drops to lowest since Sep, now -7.7%ytd. Stocks may be very oversold & sentiment is awful but unfortunately the twin vacuums of news and liquidity are making for a toxic environment right now, JPM says.

Just to put things into perspective. The 12.6% selloff in S&P 500 in Q4 2018 would be the 9th largest historically, UBS has calculated. Only Great Depression, Pearl Harbor/WWII, '87 crash and '08 crisis worse.

S&P 500 plunges to lowest since Oct2017 w/no sign of Santa Rally. Focus has shifted dramatically away from exogenous issues (trade, politics) towards something more germane to stocks & risk sentiment: growth, JPM says. Trade backdrop better than few mths, but it may be too late.
Fear Index Vix jumps 16% as S&P500 heading for new 2018 low on Fed rate-hike fear. Investors worry that another hike could bee too much for the economy and stock mkt to handle.

Don’t get too scared by flattening yield curve: S&P 500 didn’t peak for >19mths, on avg, after yield curve inverted. On avg, it gained >22% before reaching its high point. Time between inversion & recession arriving can be as long as 765 days.

The comeback of a written off tech dinosaurs: Microsoft has dethroned Apple, now more valuable than Apple for 1st time since 2010. Before that, last time 2 comps switched places was in 1989. Why this must take care of us, Slate Money explains us this week

Apple shares drop in after-hours trading after US President Trump says he would put tariffs on rest of Chinese imports if negotiations at G20 were unsuccessful. Tariffs could also be placed on iPhones imported from China. 'I can make it 10%, & people could stand that very easily'

Facebook has problems. Breaking it up would help. It’s a monopoly, having either bought or crushed most competitors. It stifles innovation, potential startups can’t get capital if venture capitalists think they might wind up as Facebook roadkill.   $FB
S&P, Dow advance on trade optimism: Trump says US may not impose more tariffs on China

The Wed reversal was discouraging as stocks looked like they would finally be able to bounce after days of selling although session could have been worse, JPM says as SPX ended off the 2746 high but also wound up closing above 2686 low; the peak-to-trough swing was dramatic ~2.1%

Apple mkt cap drops below $900bn following analyst downgrade. Apple's waning iPhone demand means big jump in prices won't be enough, Guggenheim says. iPhone supplier's guidance cuts suggest a 5% drop in 2019 iPhone unit sales, which is larger than the price increase.

Birth bias: Where mkt goes in your first 10yrs can have impact on how you think about investing for remainder of your life. 5% of all 10y periods saw neg return for S&P 500, 33.8% returns betw 5-10%. We can’t choose which of these buckets we’re born into.
Ouch! Apple briefly falls below $1 trillion market value following weak guidance and and its announcement that it will no longer disclose iPhone, iPad and Mac unit sales.
Apple drops 7% in after-hour trade following disappointing numbers and guidance. Apple will stop reporting unit sales of iPhones, iPads, and Macs beginning in fiscal 2019.
Wall St extends gains as Trump says will meet China's Xi as trade talks 'move along nicely.' BUT sounds engineered to generate an S&P bounce before mid-term elections, Bluebay’s Ash says.
CitiFX Technicals bearish for markets as monthly reversals have taken place in oil and equities that suggest further losses. Says Dow could fall to 20,428, Brent Oil to $56-$58/bbl.

S&P affirms UK's rating at 'AA'; Outlook Negative despite Brexit uncertainties, citing high income levels, diversified econ, strong institutions, & reserve currency status of sterling. Says disorderly Brexit could lead to downgrade as services sector, 3/4 of UK econ could suffer.
The S&P 500 may not yet be in correction territory, but most stocks are already in correction or bear market.
This chart suggests that S&P500 has to fall 20% as CenBank liquidity will dry up. (Chart via Standard Chartered)

Wall Street tumbled the most since Feb as fresh concern about the impact of the trade war with China roiled technology and industrial shares. Dow Jones Industrial dropped 832 points. Margin calls could trigger a bigger sell-off.

Stocks in Asia gain ahead of Fed meeting. Fed updated projections may set expectations for 2019, show neutral interest rate and highlight whether there is such a thing as a Powell put. China stocks hit 8 week high, as MSCI considers lifting index weightings. Brent hits 4y high.

S&P ups Australia's AAA credit outlook from neg to stable despite housing bubble, delivering an econ win following months of pol turmoil for Coalition govt. BUT ratings could come under pressure if house prices fall sharply and increase risks to fiscal accounts & fin stability.

Goldman joins Citigroup in flashing warnings on S&P 500. Wall Street’s voices of concern over stocks getting louder. Citi’s sentiment model signals higher chance of stock losses. Goldman says investors should be prepared for lower returns in coming years.
Emerging Markets currencies bounce despite more negative news. Argentina's B+ may be cut by S&P, which cited a weak fiscal and external profile, limited monetary flexibility and growing debt burden.

`Amazon effect' may make Central Bank job harder, Jackson Hole paper highlights. Online competition has made prices more susceptible to shocks. Average duration of prices fell as share of online sales rose.
Current US bull mkts may one of longest in US history, BUT the S&P 500 advance since March 2009 hasn't been that impressive in post-World War II terms. (via BBG)

The longest bull market in US equities may end in 2019, Capital Economics says. Expects S&P500 will end next year at 2,300. This would be a fall of almost exactly 20% from its peak. If so, the bull market would then be all but over.

Today, the S&P 500's bull-market run will turn 3,453 days old, which will make it the longest such streak in history. Bull run overtakes 3,452 days between November 1990 and March 2000, according to S&P Dow Jones indices.

In Moody's view, the probability that the Turkish authorities will manage to engineer a "soft landing" of economy is declining in the context of weakened institutions & increasing tensions w/ US. S&P expects Turkey to fall into recession next year.

The question of which stock would be 1st to reach $1tn stock mkt cap was answered last week as Apple gained 9%, Goldman says. But investors should focus on a different $1 trillion number that will have a key influence total buyback authorizations likely to be announced this year.
Who will be the first $ 1 trillion company? Shares of Amazon have climbed 56% this year, putting comp on track for a trillion-dollar valuation. But Google and Apple are still ahead.

Asia stocks gain following stellar numbers from Google. Even Yuan drop to fresh 1y low couldn't spoil the party. US 10y yields hold just below 3% while bond sell-off in Japan has stopped ahead of BoJ pol decision on July 31. Dollar steady, Bitcoin on the cusp of $8k.
Google to be fined €4.3bn by EU in Android antitrust case, equals to 0.6% of current mkt cap. The fine would top the EU’s €2.4bn antitrust decision against Google just over a year ago.

General Electric, an original member of the Dow that has been a member of the 30-stock index continuously since 1907, will be removed from the Dow Jones Industrial Average in the latest setback for the firm.
No, it's in German, but it's worth to learn German to hear it! And of course, you can leave us 5* on Apple iTunes.

Barron’s bullish for stocks citing financial engineering. Stock buybacks to hit fresh record of $650bn this yr. Offer investors effective yield of 3%, calculated by dividing repurchases by $23tn mkt value of S&P500. Combine w/2% dividend yield, investors should get 5% yld in 2018
Bitcoin drops as Buffett compared bitcoin to rat poison at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting. 87-year-old investor said bitcoin would "definitely come to a bad ending."
The most important chart in the world: Google encapsulates everything about the current age where we are in the market,  says. A must hear podcast.

Ouch! S&P lowers Turkey rating to BB- from BB; outlook to stable from negative citing macroeconomic imbalances, mainly a deterioraring current account and fiscal deficit. Says could lower rating if ext financing, Lira detoriate further.

A full-blown trade war between EU & US would be extremely costly for EU compas. S&P estimates that 23% of revenues for investment grade comps are derived from US, w/health care, business & consumer services, media, and hotels, restaurants and leisure having the largest exposure.

Facebook extends gain in after hours following bullish call. Sandberg had explained that there's no need to worry about business models beyond advertising. Even just porting all Facebook advertisers over to Instagram would be huge. And then there's Messenger, WhatsApp...

Facebook shares jumps 4.6% in after hours trading as ad sales near records and users keep flocking to the social network despite data scandal and the comp will do some financial engineering w/ additional share buyback programme.

Short sellers have been taking action in Tech sector, IHS reports, increasing bets against Facebook: Since last exchange short interest was collected for settlement on March 15th, we’ve seen a further 7m shares go on loan. IHS expects that next exchange number will print higher.
Big quarter seen for Corporate America w/ expectations that tax cuts will help S&P 500 to show its biggest quarterly profit growth in seven years.
